   Assessment and Plan
   41 year old male with a history of HTN, DM, b/l PE, pulm HTN, dCHF who
   was initially admitted to OSH for strangulated hernia.  OSH course
   complicated by difficulty weaning from vent as well as atrial flutter
   with RVR now s/p cardioversion.  Patient transfer to [**Hospital1 **] for further
   work up of SOB.
   .
   # SOB:  Patient with multiple reasons to be short of breath including
   but not limited to pulmonary HTN, PE, volume overload, dCHF, COPD or
   pneumonia.  In the setting of a recent surgery, likely volume
   overload.  Edematous on exam (not baseline per patient), reports takes
   80mg PO lasix at home but has only received 20mg PO lasix post-op.
   Patient also with fever, WBC elevation and questionable infiltrate on
   CXR making pneumonia a concern. PE less likely (adequately
   anticoagulated). COPD less likely (history unclear, ABG not
   supportive). On right heart catheterization [**7-/2143**] to close a patent
   PFO, patient was noted to have a RVEDP of 16mmHg and pulmonary artery
   pressures of 65/30 and 47 (s/d/m).  He was started on sildenafil at OSH
   although he has yet to follow up with a pulmonologist.
   - Continue IV lasix 80mg [**Hospital1 **], goal -2L qd; consider gtt if unable to
   tolerate [**2-4**] BPs
   - F/u final read of CXR
   - Continue empiric coverage vanc/zosyn for HAP
   - Follow up culture data
   - Obtain blood culture x2
   - Continue high flow oxygen overnight; consider BiPAP, ABG if
   desaturation
   - Consider CTA if not improving with diuresis
   - Upload OSH images
   - Continue sildenafil
   - Obtain echo cardiogram to assess for worsening pulmonary HTN once
   diuresed
   .
   # Pulmonary HTN: New diagnosis.  Question if secondary to chronic PEs
   of unknown origin vs idiopathic.  Patient was noted to have pulmonary
   HTN on right heart cath that was done for PFO closure.  Currently on
   sildenafil for treatment and has not yet been seen by pulmonologist as
   outpatient.  It is a potential etiology of patient
s SOB.
   - Continue sildenafil
   - Continue SOB treatment per above
   - Needs outpatient pulmonology f/u
   - Obtain echo cardiogram to assess for worsening pulmonary HTN once
   diuresed
   .
   # Chronic PEs: Unclear etiology, questionable secondary to stasis with
   pulmonary HTN.  Patient was supposed to have hypercoagulable work up in
   past.  No evidence of new clots since his PFO closed.  Currently
   patient remains on hep gtt and plavix.  Per medical records, he had a
   clot while on therapeutic dose of coumadin and so presumably plavix was
   added.
   - Continue anticoagulation with hep gtt and plavix
   - Upload OSH images
   - Consider CTA if not improving with diuresis
   .
   # Fever/leukocytosis: Likely [**2-4**] infection. Questionable infiltrate on
   CXR; also s/p abdominal recent surgery. At this time treating broadly
   for infection and covering for HAP given desats and possible infiltrate
   on CXR.
   - F/u final read of CXR
   - F/u culture data
   - Consider CT abdomen if leukocytosis not resolving
   - Serial abdominal exam
   - Continue empiric coverage vanc/zosyn for HAP
   .
   # Elevated ALT: [**Month (only) 11**] represent viral hepatitis although in the setting
   of volume overload likely is mild congestive hepatopathy.
   - Trend ALT
   - Consider checking hepatitis serologies if not improving
   .
   # Anemia: 29.1 from 40.3 last [**Month (only) 93**]. Likely related to prolonged
   hospital stay and recent surgery.  Given anticoagulation GI bleed
   certainly a concern.
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Trend hct
   - Consider transfuse for goal hct > 21 or unstable
   .
   # Diabetes: Insulin SS for now.  Can change to outpatient regimen when
   closer to discharge.
   .
   # Med rec: Unclear why patient is on digoxin.  Presumably rate control
   with sotalol for rhythm control in a-flutter or possible also treatment
   of pulmonary HTN.  Unclear if patient will need these medications in
   the long term as flutter occurred in the peri-op setting.
   .
   # h/o a-flutter: s/p cardioversion. Continue sotalol and digoxin as
   patient currently stable.  Question continued need for digoxin at this
   time given fact that he is in sinus.  Will ultimately need a
   cardiologist to follow up with re: sotalol.  Patient being
   anticoagulated for other reasons already.
   .
   # Strangulated bowel: s/p surgery.  Continue to monitor BMs.  Daily
   dressing changes.
   - Continue to follow
   - Serial abdominal exam
   .
   # GERD: continue PPI
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Hold Zocor acutely, can restart when closer to
   discharge.
   .
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, regular diabetic diet
   # Prophylaxis: hep gtt
   # Access: Peripherals
   # Communication: Patient
   # Code:  Full (discussed with patient)
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:

   22 Gauge - [**2144-1-8**] 01:40 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:

   Code status: Full code

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 41-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of hypertension, diabetes, bilateral pulmonary embolism, pulmonary hypertension, and decompensated congestive heart failure. He was initially admitted for a strangulated hernia, which complicated his course with difficulty weaning from the ventilator and atrial flutter with right ventricular overload.

The patient's current condition is characterized by shortness of breath, fever, and leukocytosis, with a questionable infiltrate on the chest X-ray. He has a history of chronic pulmonary embolism, pulmonary hypertension, and atrial flutter. He is currently being treated for hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.8Â°C, heart rate of 83 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 101/58 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 23 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 91%. His laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, elevated creatinine, and low hemoglobin.

The patient's physical examination is notable for bilateral crackles in the lungs, soft abdomen with a surgical incision site, and 2+ pitting edema in both lower extremities. He has a Foley catheter in place and is receiving high-flow oxygen.

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:

1. Pulmonary hypertension: New diagnosis, potentially secondary to chronic pulmonary embolism or idiopathic. The patient is currently being treated with sildenafil.
2. Chronic pulmonary embolism: Unclear etiology, potentially secondary to stasis with pulmonary hypertension. The patient is being anticoagulated with heparin and plavix.
3. Fever and leukocytosis: Likely due to infection, possibly pneumonia or a secondary infection. The patient is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.
4. Elevated ALT: Likely due to mild congestive hepatopathy, possibly related to volume overload.
5. Anemia: Likely related to prolonged hospital stay and recent surgery. The patient is being monitored for GI bleeding.
6. Diabetes: Insulin is being used for glycemic control.
7. Atrial flutter: The patient has undergone cardioversion and is currently being treated with sotalol and digoxin.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Worsening pulmonary hypertension
2. Development of pneumonia or secondary infections
3. GI bleeding due to anemia or anticoagulation
4. Volume overload or congestive heart failure
5. Pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis
6. Electrolyte imbalances or hyperkalemia
7. Hepatotoxicity or liver failure

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, the following plan is recommended:

1. Continue empiric coverage for HAP with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam.
2. Monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust antibiotics as necessary.
3. Consider CTA if the patient's symptoms do not improve with diuresis.
4. Continue anticoagulation with heparin and plavix.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust treatment as necessary.
6. Consider checking hepatitis serologies if the patient's ALT levels do not improve.
7. Continue insulin therapy for glycemic control.
8. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust treatment as necessary.
9. Consider obtaining an echocardiogram to assess for worsening pulmonary hypertension.
10. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust treatment as necessary.

In conclusion, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications. A multidisciplinary approach involving cardiothoracic surgeons, pulmonologists, and intensivists is necessary to optimize the patient's care and improve his outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of hypertension, diabetes, bilateral pulmonary embolism, pulmonary hypertension, and dilated cardiomyopathy who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to shortness of breath. He was initially treated for atrial flutter with cardioversion and has been receiving empiric coverage for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). The patient's condition is complicated by volume overload, pulmonary hypertension, and possible pneumonia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening Pulmonary Hypertension: The patient's pulmonary hypertension is likely to worsen due to the presence of pulmonary embolism, volume overload, and possible pneumonia.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has a questionable infiltrate on the chest X-ray and is receiving empiric coverage for HAP. The risk of pneumonia is high, especially in the setting of recent surgery and volume overload.
3. Volume Overload: The patient has evidence of volume overload, which can worsen his pulmonary hypertension and increase the risk of cardiac complications.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of dilated cardiomyopathy and atrial flutter with cardioversion increases his risk of cardiac complications, including heart failure and arrhythmias.
5. Fever and Leukocytosis: The patient has a fever and leukocytosis, which may be indicative of an underlying infection. The possibility of a secondary infection should be considered, especially in the setting of recent surgery.
6. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which may be related to prolonged hospital stay, recent surgery, and anticoagulation therapy. GI bleeding is a concern, especially in the setting of anticoagulation therapy.
7. Elevated ALT: The patient has elevated ALT levels, which may be related to viral hepatitis or mild congestive hepatopathy. Trending ALT levels and considering hepatitis serologies if not improving is recommended.
8. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has a history of hyperlipidemia, which should be monitored and managed during his hospital stay.

Recommendations:

1. Continue empiric coverage for HAP with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam.
2. Monitor the patient's pulmonary hypertension and consider vasodilator therapy if necessary.
3. Manage the patient's volume overload with diuretics and continue to monitor his cardiac status.
4. Consider obtaining a CT scan of the chest and abdomen to evaluate for pulmonary embolism and other complications.
5. Continue anticoagulation therapy with heparin and clopidogrel.
6. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusion if necessary.
7. Trend ALT levels and consider hepatitis serologies if not improving.
8. Continue to manage the patient's hyperlipidemia and consider restarting Zocor when closer to discharge.

Summary:

The patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of PFO repair, recurrent PEs, pulmonary HTN, and dCHF, currently in the ICU following strangulated hernia repair. He has ongoing hypoxemia, episode of atrial flutter with RVR, and severe pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. The patient has been diagnosed with HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP, and empiric coverage with vanc/zosyn has been initiated. He is also being treated for pulmonary hypertension with sildenafil and heparin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypoxemia and severe pulmonary artery systolic hypertension may lead to respiratory failure, requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever, leukocytosis, and questionable infiltrate on CXR may indicate sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ dysfunction and death.
3. Pulmonary Embolism: Although the patient is adequately anticoagulated, there is a risk of new PE, especially given his history of recurrent PEs.
4. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's atrial flutter and RVR may lead to cardiac arrest, especially if not properly managed.
5. GI Bleed: The patient's anemia and prolonged hospital stay may increase the risk of GI bleed, especially with anticoagulation therapy.
6. Infection: The patient's low-grade fever and leukocytosis may indicate an underlying infection, which could spread to other parts of the body.
7. Pulmonary Hypertension: The patient's severe pulmonary artery systolic hypertension may worsen his condition, leading to right heart failure and death.
8. Hepatic Dysfunction: The patient's elevated ALT and possible congestive hepatopathy may indicate liver damage, which could lead to liver failure.
9. Wound Complications: The patient's serosanguinous leak from wound and prolonged hospital stay may increase the risk of wound complications, such as infection or dehiscence.

Based on this information, it is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status closely to prevent or detect these potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of PFO repair, recurrent PEs, pulmonary HTN, and dCHF. He is currently in the ICU with ongoing hypoxemia, fever, and leukocytosis. He has undergone surgery for a strangulated hernia repair and is experiencing respiratory distress.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Pneumonia/VAP:** The patient's low-grade fever, leukocytosis, and questionable infiltrate on CXR suggest the possibility of nosocomial pneumonia or VAP. Empiric coverage with vanc/zosyn has been started.
2. **Pulmonary Hypertension:** The patient has severe pulmonary hypertension, which is likely worsening from prior. Unifying diagnosis unclear, but considering CTA once able to tolerate prone position.
3. **Chronic PEs:** The patient has a history of recurrent PEs, and anticoagulation with heparin gtt and plavix is ongoing.
4. **Fever/Leukocytosis:** The patient's fever and leukocytosis may be related to infection, with a source likely to be pulmonary.
5. **Hypokalemia:** The patient has hypokalemia, which needs to be aggressively managed with KCl prn.
6. **Elevated ALT:** The patient's elevated ALT is trending down, but may represent mild congestive hepatopathy.
7. **Anemia:** The patient's anemia is likely related to prolonged hospital stay and recent surgery with serosanguinous leak from wound.
8. **H/O Strangulated Bowel:** The patient's history of strangulated bowel and ongoing serosanguinous leak from wound requires close monitoring.
9. **A-Flutter:** The patient has a history of a-flutter and is currently stable on sotalol and digoxin, but may need a cardiologist to follow up with re: sotalol.
10. **Genetic Diagnosis:** The patient's dysmorphic facies may be related to a unifying genetic diagnosis, and a geneticist consultation is being considered.

**Plan:**

1. Continue empiric coverage with vanc/zosyn for HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP.
2. Start lasix gtt and continue IV diamox 500mg.
3. Check PM electrolytes and replete with KCl prn.
4. Repeat CXR and consider CTA once able to tolerate prone position.
5. Continue anticoagulation with heparin gtt and plavix.
6. Monitor BMs and consider transfusing for goal Hct > 21 or unstable.
7. Continue daily dressing changes and serial abdominal exams.
8. Continue sotalol and digoxin as patient is currently stable, but may need a cardiologist to follow up with re: sotalol.
9. Consider curbside geneticist consultation to discuss patient's dysmorphic facies.
10. Monitor patient's clinical condition and adjust plan as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 41-year-old male with a complex medical history, including a history of PFO repair, recurrent PEs, pulmonary HTN, and dCHF. He is currently in the ICU for post-operative care after a strangulated hernia repair.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.8Â°C, heart rate of 73 bpm, and blood pressure of 97/54 mmHg. He has a history of hypoxemia and SOB, which is likely related to volume overload and pulmonary HTN. He also has a history of fever, leukocytosis, and questionable infiltrate on CXR, which may be related to nosocomial pneumonia or VAP.

The patient is receiving treatment for pulmonary HTN, including sildenafil and heparin, and is also receiving empiric coverage for HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam. He has a history of thrombocytosis and is receiving anticoagulation therapy with heparin and plavix.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 15.3, hemoglobin of 9.1 g/dL, and platelet count of 163,000. His electrolyte levels are slightly abnormal, with a potassium level of 3.8 mEq/L and a magnesium level of 1.3 mg/dL.

The patient's physical examination is notable for bilateral rales, a soft and non-tender abdomen, and 2+ DP pulses and 2+ bilateral lower extremity pitting edema.

The patient's diagnosis is complex and multifactorial, and may include pulmonary HTN, dCHF, hypoxemia, SOB, fever, leukocytosis, and nosocomial pneumonia or VAP. He requires continued treatment and monitoring in the ICU to address these issues and prevent further complications.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Pneumonia or VAP: The patient's history of fever, leukocytosis, and questionable infiltrate on CXR suggests that he may have a nosocomial pneumonia or VAP. If this is the case, he may require further antibiotics and treatment.
2. Pulmonary HTN: The patient's history of pulmonary HTN and dCHF puts him at risk for further complications, including pulmonary edema and right ventricular failure. He may require further treatment with sildenafil and heparin to manage his pulmonary HTN.
3. Hypokalemia: The patient's potassium level is slightly abnormal, and he may require further treatment with potassium supplements to manage his hypokalemia.
4. Thrombocytosis: The patient's platelet count is slightly abnormal, and he may require further treatment with antiplatelet agents to manage his thrombocytosis.
5. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is slightly abnormal, and he may require further treatment with blood transfusions to manage his anemia.
6. Fever and leukocytosis: The patient's fever and leukocytosis may be related to an underlying infection, and he may require further treatment with antibiotics and other medications to manage these symptoms.
7. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's history of recurrent PEs puts him at risk for further complications, including pulmonary embolism. He may require further treatment with anticoagulation therapy and other medications to manage this risk.

Overall, the patient's complex medical history and current condition require careful monitoring and treatment in the ICU to prevent further complications and promote recovery.

Summary:

The patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of PFO repair, recurrent PEs, pulmonary HTN, and dCHF. He was admitted to the ICU for a strangulated hernia repair and is currently on day 15 of his hospital stay. He is experiencing worsening hypoxemia, volume overload, and a possible nosocomial pneumonia. He has a history of pulmonary HTN, dCHF, and PEs, and is currently on anticoagulation therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Nosocomial pneumonia: The patient's worsening hypoxemia and fever, along with the presence of a questionable infiltrate on his CXR, suggest the possibility of a nosocomial pneumonia. This is further supported by the fact that he has a history of pulmonary HTN and dCHF, which can increase his risk of developing pneumonia.
2. Volume overload: The patient's fluid balance data shows a significant amount of fluid being administered, which may be contributing to his volume overload. This can lead to worsening hypoxemia, increased cardiac workload, and decreased renal function.
3. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient's electrolyte data shows a significant decrease in his potassium levels, which may be related to his volume overload and metabolic alkalosis. This can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other systemic complications.
4. Sepsis: The patient's fever and leukocytosis suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can be caused by a variety of factors, including pneumonia, urinary tract infection, or intra-abdominal infection.
5. Pulmonary HTN: The patient's history of pulmonary HTN and his current symptoms of worsening hypoxemia and volume overload suggest that his pulmonary HTN may be worsening. This can lead to increased cardiac workload, decreased renal function, and decreased exercise tolerance.
6. dCHF: The patient's history of dCHF and his current symptoms of worsening hypoxemia and volume overload suggest that his dCHF may be worsening. This can lead to increased cardiac workload, decreased renal function, and decreased exercise tolerance.
7. Thrombocytosis: The patient's thrombocytosis may be related to his recent surgery and may be a sign of a reactive process. However, it can also be a sign of a underlying bleeding disorder or a sign of a neoplastic process.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue lasix gtt and monitor for volume overload.
2. Continue IV diamox and monitor for metabolic alkalosis.
3. Check PM electrolytes and replete potassium levels as needed.
4. Order an AM CXR to monitor for any changes in his lung disease.
5. Continue empiric coverage for HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP.
6. Re-obtain sputum culture and follow up with culture data.
7. Consider CTA and CT abdomen if the patient's symptoms worsen or do not improve.
8. Continue high flow oxygen and consider BiPAP or intubation if the patient's oxygenation worsens.
9. Monitor the patient's digoxin level and consider adjusting his dosage as needed.
10. Continue to trend the patient's ALT and consider checking hepatitis serologies if his ALT levels continue to rise.
11. Continue to monitor the patient's Hct and consider transfusing if his Hct levels drop below 21.
12. Continue to trend the patient's platelet count and consider transfusing if his platelet count drops below 20,000.
13. Continue to monitor the patient's wound and consider surgical consultation if the wound becomes unstable.
14. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider cardiologist consultation if his cardiac status worsens.

Summary:

The patient is a 41-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of pulmonary hypertension, chronic pulmonary embolism, and a recent strangulated hernia repair. He is currently experiencing hypoxemia, volume overload, and a suspected nosocomial pneumonia. He is receiving empiric coverage with vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam, and his antibiotics will be continued for 3-4 days. The patient's pulmonary hypertension is being managed with sildenafil, heparin, and digoxin, and he will be continued on these medications. The patient's thrombocytosis is likely reactive to the splenectomy, and his anemia is likely related to prolonged hospital stay and recent surgery. The patient's electrolyte levels are being closely monitored, and he will be aggressively managed to keep his potassium levels above 4.5.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Nosocomial pneumonia: The patient's hypoxemia and suspected nosocomial pneumonia may lead to further respiratory complications, such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or septic shock.
2. Pulmonary hypertension: The patient's severe pulmonary hypertension may lead to further complications, such as right ventricular failure or cardiac arrest.
3. Volume overload: The patient's volume overload may lead to further complications, such as heart failure or pulmonary edema.
4. Infection: The patient's suspected nosocomial pneumonia may lead to further infections, such as bacteremia or sepsis.
5. Thrombocytosis: The patient's thrombocytosis may lead to further complications, such as bleeding or thrombotic events.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may lead to further complications, such as heart failure or cardiac arrest.
7. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte imbalance may lead to further complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or muscle weakness.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and recent surgery may lead to further complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding.
9. Cardiac arrest: The patient's history of a-flutter and recent cardioversion may lead to further complications, such as cardiac arrest.
10. Sepsis: The patient's suspected nosocomial pneumonia may lead to further complications, such as sepsis or septic shock.

   41 year old male with a history of PFO repair, recurrent PEs, pulmonary

   overload s/p surgery consistent with exam and not taking home dose
   lasix post-op. Further, [**2-4**] nosocomial pneumonia, VAP as patient also
   with low-grade fever, leukocytosis, questionable infiltrate on CXR with
   hx productive cough. Also may be related with severe pulmonary HTN,
   dCHF (bNP 3000s). New PE less likely (adequately anticoagulated).
   Likely related with a combination of the above.
   - Continue lasix gtt today with goal -1L
   - Continue IV diamox 500mg if alkalosis on PM lytes
   - Continue Heparin gtt.
   - Check PM electrolytes; replete prn with goal to keep K > 4.5
   (aggressive KCl repletion given metabolic alkalosis); d/c lasix if Cr
   elevates
   - Order AM CXR
   - Continue empiric coverage vanc/zosyn for HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP
   (currently day 4)
   - Re-obtain sputum culture [**2-4**] to contamination x 2
   - Follow up cultures
   - Continue high flow oxygen with plans for BiPAP, ABG if desaturation
   or intubation
   - If worsens/ does not improve, consider CTA and CT abdomen
   - Will need PICC line for access after resolution of fevers; try for
   this PM
   - Check sed rate, [**Doctor First Name **] r/o rheumatologic diagnoses
   .
   # Pulmonary HTN: Stable, severe. Unifying diagnosis unclear given PFO,
   craniofacial facies, hypercoagulability, developmental delay.
   Appreciate recs from Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 10291**].
   - Continue sildenafil/heparin gtt/digoxin for pulmonary hypertension
   - Continue to monitor digoxin level ([**1-8**] digoxin level 0.2, [**1-10**] digoxin
   level 0.5)
   - Consider PAC with vasodilator trial if no improvement
   - Obtain genetic karyotype and needs follow up as outpatient
   .
   # Chronic PEs: Unclear etiology, questionable secondary to stasis with
   pulmonary HTN. Plavix was added to regimen as he presumably had clot
   while on therapeutic dose of coumadin.  Patient was supposed to have
   hypercoagulable work up in past.  No evidence of new clots since his
   PFO closed.  Currently patient remains on hep gtt and plavix.
   - Continue anticoagulation with heparin gtt
   - plavix stopoped
   - If worsens/ does not improve, consider CTA and CT abdomen
   .
   # Fever/leukocytosis: Likely [**2-4**] infection with source likely to be
   pulmonary. Abdominal exam s/p surgery unremarkable.
   - Will need repeat sputum culture
   - Continue empiric coverage vanc/zosyn for HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP
   (currently day 3)
   - Follow up culture data
   - Follow up HIV status (consent obtained and sent [**1-8**])
   - Continue serial abdominal exams
   .
   # Hypokalemia: Will need to be aggressively managed. K goal of 4.5.
   - Check PM electrolytes; replete prn with goal to keep K > 4.5
   (aggressive KCl repletion given metabolic alkalosis)
   .
   # Anemia: 30 and stable, (40.3 last [**Month (only) 93**]). Likely related to prolonged
   hospital stay and recent surgery with serosanguinous leak from wound.
   Given anticoagulation, consider GI bleed.
   - Continue to guaiac all stools
   - Continue to trend Hct
   - Consider transfuse for goal Hct > 21 or unstable
   .
   # Thrombocytosis: Stable; likely reactive [**2-4**] splenectomy.
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # h/o strangulated bowel: s/p surgery.  Continue to monitor BMs.
   - Continue daily dressing changes
   - Continue serial abdominal exams
   - Obtain surgical consultation if becomes unstable; otherwise needs
   keep outpatient surgical follow up
   .
   # h/o a-flutter s/p cardioversion. Continue sotalol and digoxin as
   patient currently stable.  Question continued need for digoxin at this
   time given fact that he is in sinus.  Will ultimately need a
   cardiologist to follow up with re: sotalol.  Patient being
   anticoagulated for other reasons already.
   - Continue to monitor digoxin level ([**1-8**] digoxin level 0.2, [**1-10**] digoxin
   level 0.5)
   .
   # Diabetes: Continue ISS with change to outpatient regimen when closer
   to discharge.
   .
   # GERD: Continue PPI.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Hold Zocor acutely, can restart when closer to
   discharge.
   .
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes aggressively as on digoxin, sotalol
   and lasix gtt, regular diabetic diet
   # Prophylaxis: hep gtt, famotidine, bowel regimen with miralax prn
   constipation
   # Access: Peripherals; Will need PICC line for access after resolution
   of fevers; try for this PM
   # Communication: Patient; Will get in touch with patient

Summary:

The patient is a 41-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of pulmonary hypertension, recurrent pulmonary embolism, and deep vein thrombosis. He underwent strangulated hernia repair and is currently on mechanical ventilation. The patient's condition is stable, but he is experiencing hypoxemia, volume overload, and suspected nosocomial pneumonia. He is also on anticoagulation therapy for pulmonary embolism and has a history of atrial flutter.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Nosocomial Pneumonia: The patient's symptoms of fever, leukocytosis, and worsening hypoxemia suggest a possible nosocomial pneumonia. The patient's history of smoking and chronic pulmonary hypertension may increase his risk of developing pneumonia.
2. Volume Overload: The patient's fluid overload may be contributing to his worsening hypoxemia and may require further management.
3. Pulmonary Embolism: Although the patient is on anticoagulation therapy, there is still a risk of recurrent pulmonary embolism, especially given his history of recurrent pulmonary embolism.
4. Atrial Flutter: The patient's history of atrial flutter and his current use of sotalol may increase his risk of developing a life-threatening arrhythmia.
5. Sepsis: The patient's fever, leukocytosis, and worsening hypoxemia may indicate the development of sepsis, which could be life-threatening.
6. Gastrointestinal Bleed: The patient's history of anticoagulation and his current use of warfarin may increase his risk of developing a gastrointestinal bleed.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytosis may be a sign of a bleeding disorder or may be related to his current use of anticoagulation therapy.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be related to his prolonged hospital stay, recent surgery, and serosanguinous leak from his wound.

Recommendations:

1. Continue anticoagulation therapy to prevent recurrent pulmonary embolism.
2. Manage the patient's fluid overload by adjusting his fluid intake and output.
3. Consider empirical coverage for nosocomial pneumonia with antibiotics.
4. Monitor the patient's oxygen saturation and adjust his oxygen therapy as needed.
5. Consider a vasodilator trial to improve the patient's pulmonary hypertension.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust his antiarrhythmic therapy as needed.
7. Consider a gastrointestinal bleed workup if the patient develops signs of bleeding.
8. Monitor the patient's platelet count and adjust his anticoagulation therapy as needed.
9. Consider transfusing the patient if his hemoglobin level falls below 7 g/dL.
10. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his electrolyte replacement as needed.

   Assessment and Plan
   41 year old male with a history of PFO repair, recurrent PEs, pulmonary
   HTN, dCHF POD #15 strangulated hernia repair slow vent wean with
   improving hypoxemia and volume overload.
   # Hypoexemia/SOB: Multifactorial as stated below. Continues to improve.
   Likely major contributors are pulmonary hypertension, pulmonary edema
   and likely infiltrate/infection. Also important to consider possible
   pulmonary emboli. [**Month (only) 11**] likely be [**2-4**] volume overload s/p surgery
   consistent with exam and not taking home dose lasix post-op. Further,
   [**2-4**] nosocomial pneumonia, VAP as patient also with low-grade fever,
   leukocytosis, questionable infiltrate on CXR with hx productive cough.
   Also may be related with severe pulmonary HTN, dCHF (bNP 3000s). New PE
   less likely (adequately anticoagulated). Likely related with a
   combination of the above.
   - CTA
   - NAC 600 mg x 4
   - Temporarily hold Lasix today after CTAContinue lasix gtt today with
   goal -1L
   - Continue Heparin gtt.
   - Check PM electrolytes; replete prn with goal to keep K > 4.5
   (aggressive KCl repletion given metabolic alkalosis); d/c lasix if Cr
   elevates
   - Continue empiric coverage vanc/zosyn for HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP
   (currently day 5)
   - Follow up cultures
   - Continue high flow oxygen, but wean today to 40%
   # Pulmonary HTN
   Stable, severe. Unifying diagnosis unclear given PFO, craniofacial
   facies, hypercoagulability, developmental delay. Likely secondary to
   PFO
   - Continue sildenafil/heparin gtt/digoxin for pulmonary hypertension
   - Continue to monitor digoxin level
   # Genetic Syndrome
   Clear dysmorphic features and possibility of serious sequelae.
   Therefore send karyotype and on that basis determine if further
   outpatient workup is necessary.
   - Karyotype
   # Chronic PEs
   Unclear etiology, likely secondary and also exacerbating pulmonary HTN.
   Plavix was added to regimen as he presumably had clot while on
   therapeutic dose of coumadin. Patient was supposed to have
   hypercoagulable work up in past, but this may be worth revisiting
   (again as an outpatient).  No evidence of new clots since his PFO
   closed. Currently patient remains on hep gtt (plavix stopped).
   - Continue anticoagulation with heparin gtt
   # Fever/leukocytosis
   Both are improving. Likely because of antibiotic therapy. WBC now 11s
   and afebrile. Source likely pulmonary. No other findings suggestive of
   infection elsewhere.
   - Continue empiric coverage vanc/zosyn for HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP
   (currently day 3)
   - Follow up culture data
   # Hypokalemia: Will need to be aggressively managed. K goal of 4.5.
   - Check PM electrolytes; replete prn with goal to keep K > 4.5
   (aggressive KCl repletion given metabolic alkalosis)
   # Anemia
   Near 30 and stable, (40.3 last [**Month (only) 93**]). Likely related to prolonged
   hospital stay and recent surgery with serosanguinous leak from wound.
   Now suppression likely given present infection. Given anticoagulation,
   consider GI bleed.
   - Guaiac stools again if suspicion of losses
   - Continue to trend Hct
   - Consider transfuse for goal Hct > 21 or unstable
   # Thrombocytosis: Stable; likely reactive [**2-4**] splenectomy.
   - Continue to trend
   # h/o strangulated bowel: s/p surgery.  Continue to monitor BMs.
   - Continue daily dressing changes
   - Now daily careful abdominal exams
   - Obtain surgical consultation if becomes unstable; otherwise needs
   keep outpatient surgical follow up
   # h/o a-flutter s/p cardioversion. Continue sotalol and digoxin as
   patient currently stable.  Question continued need for digoxin at this
   time given fact that he is in sinus.  Will ultimately need a
   cardiologist to follow up with re: sotalol.  Patient being
   anticoagulated for other reasons already.
   - Continue to monitor digoxin level ([**1-8**] digoxin level 0.2, [**1-10**] digoxin
   level 0.5)
   # Diabetes: Continue ISS with change to outpatient regimen when closer
   to discharge.
   # GERD: Continue PPI.
   # Hyperlipidemia: Hold Zocor acutely, can restart when closer to
   discharge.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes aggressively as on digoxin, sotalol
   and lasix gtt, regular diabetic diet
   # Prophylaxis: hep gtt, famotidine, bowel regimen with miralax prn
   constipation
   # Access: Peripherals; Will need PICC line for access after resolution
   of fevers; try for this PM
   # Communication: Patient; Will get in touch with patient
s father

Summary:

The patient is a 41-year-old male who has been admitted to the ICU with a history of pulmonary hypertension, dCHF, and recurrent PEs. He underwent strangulated hernia repair and is currently on mechanical ventilation. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 64 bpm, blood pressure of 109/57 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94%. He has a fever and leukocytosis, which is likely related to a pulmonary infection. The patient's laboratory results show anemia, thrombocytosis, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary embolism (PE): Given the patient's history of recurrent PEs and pulmonary hypertension, there is a high risk of developing a PE.
2. Nosocomial pneumonia (HAP/VAP): The patient's fever and leukocytosis, along with the presence of a pulmonary infiltrate on chest X-ray, suggest a possible pulmonary infection.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic pulmonary hypertension and recent surgery may lead to respiratory failure if not properly managed.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial flutter and use of digoxin and sotalol increase the risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.
5. GI bleed: The patient's anemia and recent surgery may increase the risk of developing a GI bleed, particularly with anticoagulation therapy.
6. Renal failure: The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and use of diuretics may increase the risk of developing acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
7. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's use of diuretics and electrolyte supplements may lead to electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypokalemia.
8. Infection: The patient's fever and leukocytosis suggest a possible infection, which may be related to the pulmonary infiltrate or other sources.
9. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytosis may increase the risk of developing thrombocytopenia, particularly with anticoagulation therapy.
10. Cardiac failure: The patient's chronic pulmonary hypertension and recent surgery may lead to cardiac failure if not properly managed.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Patient Information:**

* 41-year-old male with a history of PFO repair, recurrent PEs, pulmonary HTN, dCHF, and strangulated hernia repair.
* Currently in the ICU with hypoxemia, SOB, and volume overload.

**Medical Complications:**

1. **Nosocomial Pneumonia/VAP:** The patient has a history of productive cough, low-grade fever, and leukocytosis, which may be related to a nosocomial pneumonia or VAP. Empiric coverage with Vanc/Zosyn has been initiated.
2. **Pulmonary HTN:** The patient has severe pulmonary HTN, which may be related to his history of PFO repair, craniofacial facies, hypercoagulability, and developmental delay. Sildenafil, heparin, and digoxin are being used to manage his pulmonary HTN.
3. **Chronic PEs:** The patient has a history of recurrent PEs, which may be related to his hypercoagulable state. Anticoagulation with heparin and Plavix is being used to manage his PEs.
4. **Fever/Leukocytosis:** The patient has a fever and leukocytosis, which may be related to an underlying infection. Repeat sputum cultures and empiric coverage with Vanc/Zosyn have been initiated.
5. **Hypokalemia:** The patient has hypokalemia, which may be related to his diuretic therapy. Aggressive potassium repletion is necessary to maintain a potassium level of 4.5.
6. **Anemia:** The patient has anemia, which may be related to his prolonged hospital stay and recent surgery. Transfusion may be necessary to maintain a hemoglobin level of 21.
7. **Thrombocytosis:** The patient has thrombocytosis, which may be related to his splenectomy. Monitoring of his platelet count is necessary to ensure that it remains stable.
8. **Sepsis:** The patient has a history of strangulated bowel and may be at risk for sepsis. Monitoring of his vital signs and serial abdominal exams is necessary to detect any signs of sepsis.
9. **Cardiac Issues:** The patient has a history of a-flutter and has been treated with cardioversion. He is currently on digoxin and sotalol, and his digoxin level will need to be monitored.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient's hypoxemia and SOB may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
2. **Cardiac Arrest:** The patient's history of a-flutter and his current cardiac medications may increase his risk of cardiac arrest.
3. **Sepsis:** The patient's history of strangulated bowel and his current infections may lead to sepsis.
4. **Gastrointestinal Bleeding:** The patient's anemia and thrombocytosis may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. **Renal Failure:** The patient's diuretic therapy and his underlying medical conditions may increase his risk of renal failure.

**Plan:**

1. Continue lasix gtt to manage volume overload and hypokalemia.
2. Continue empiric coverage with Vanc/Zosyn for nosocomial pneumonia/VAP.
3. Monitor the patient's digoxin level and adjust his digoxin therapy as necessary.
4. Continue anticoagulation with heparin and Plavix for chronic PEs.
5. Monitor the patient's platelet count and adjust his platelet therapy as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and serial abdominal exams to detect any signs of sepsis.
7. Consider CTA and CT abdomen if the patient's condition worsens or does not improve.
8. Continue to communicate with the patient's family and provide updates on his condition.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 41-year-old male with a complex medical history, including a history of PFO repair, recurrent pulmonary emboli, pulmonary hypertension, and dilated cardiomyopathy. He is currently admitted to the ICU for management of acute hypoxemia, volume overload, and suspected nosocomial pneumonia.

The patient's current vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.7Â°C (98.1Â°F)
* Heart rate: 64 bpm
* Blood pressure: 109/57 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 28 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 94%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Central venous pressure (CVP) and pulmonary artery catheter (PAC) are in place.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 13.9 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 28.5%
* Platelet count: 11.9 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 25 mEq/L
* Electrolytes: Potassium 4.3 mEq/L, magnesium 2.2 mg/dL, phosphorus 4.3 mg/dL
* Glucose: 163 mg/dL
* Blood cultures: Gram-positive cocci in clusters

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray (CXR): Suggestive of possible infiltrate or pneumonia
* Computed tomography (CT) angiogram: Not performed yet

The patient's medical plan includes:

* Continuation of empiric antibiotics (vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam) for suspected nosocomial pneumonia
* Temporarily holding furosemide (Lasix) due to concerns about volume overload and potential electrolyte imbalances
* Continuing heparin infusion for anticoagulation
* Monitoring digoxin levels and adjusting as needed
* Aggressive management of hypokalemia with potassium repletion
* Serial abdominal exams to monitor for potential bowel obstruction or perforation
* Follow-up cultures and imaging studies as needed

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Progression of nosocomial pneumonia or development of new infections
* Volume overload and worsening of pulmonary edema
* Electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypokalemia and hyperkalemia
* Thrombotic complications, including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE)
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to anticoagulation or underlying gastrointestinal disease
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to digoxin or other medications
* Worsening of pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular dysfunction

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, close monitoring and multidisciplinary care are necessary to manage his condition and prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 41-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of PFO repair, recurrent PEs, pulmonary HTN, and dCHF. He underwent strangulated hernia repair and is experiencing worsening hypoxemia, SOB, and volume overload. He has a suspected nosocomial pneumonia, VAP, and is on empiric coverage with Vanc/Zosyn. His labs show anemia, thrombocytosis, and metabolic alkalosis, and he is at risk for GI bleed and hypokalemia. He is also on anticoagulation therapy for chronic PEs and pulmonary HTN.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Nosocomial pneumonia/VAP: The patient's symptoms of SOB, cough, and low-grade fever, along with the presence of a suspected infiltrate on CXR, suggest the possibility of nosocomial pneumonia or VAP. Continued empiric coverage with Vanc/Zosyn is necessary.
2. Pulmonary HTN: The patient's severe pulmonary HTN is a significant concern, and the unifying diagnosis is unclear. Further evaluation with a genetic karyotype and follow-up as an outpatient are necessary.
3. Chronic PEs: The patient's history of recurrent PEs and the presence of anticoagulation therapy suggest the possibility of ongoing clotting. Further evaluation with CTA and CT abdomen may be necessary if the patient's condition worsens or does not improve.
4. Hypokalemia: The patient's hypokalemia is a significant concern, and aggressive management with KCl repletion is necessary to maintain a goal potassium level of 4.5.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely related to prolonged hospital stay, recent surgery, and serosanguinous leak from the wound. Close monitoring of Hct and consideration of transfusion for goal Hct > 21 or unstable is necessary.
6. Thrombocytosis: The patient's thrombocytosis is likely reactive to the splenectomy. Close monitoring of platelet count is necessary.
7. GI bleed: The patient's anticoagulation therapy and history of strangulated bowel make him at risk for GI bleed. Close monitoring of stool guaiac and serial abdominal exams is necessary.
8. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient's metabolic alkalosis is likely related to the diuretic therapy and requires close monitoring of electrolytes and consideration of KCl repletion.

ICU Care Plan:

1. Continue empiric coverage with Vanc/Zosyn for nosocomial pneumonia/VAP.
2. Continue anticoagulation therapy for chronic PEs and pulmonary HTN.
3. Aggressively manage hypokalemia with KCl repletion.
4. Close monitor Hct and consider transfusion for goal Hct > 21 or unstable.
5. Monitor platelet count and consider transfusion if necessary.
6. Monitor stool guaiac and serial abdominal exams for GI bleed.
7. Consider CTA and CT abdomen if the patient's condition worsens or does not improve.
8. Continue to monitor digoxin level and consider stopping digoxin if the patient is in sinus rhythm.
9. Continue to monitor sotalol and consider follow-up with a cardiologist.
10. Continue to manage diabetes, GERD, and hyperlipidemia as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of PFO repair, recurrent PEs, pulmonary hypertension, and dCHF. He is currently in the ICU with worsening respiratory status after a strangulated hernia repair. He has been diagnosed with hypoxemia, pulmonary edema, and likely infiltrate/infection. The patient is being treated with diuresis, antibiotics, and oxygen therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The patient has a history of recurrent PEs and is at risk for developing another PE, especially with his current respiratory status.
2. Nosocomial Pneumonia (HAP/VAP): The patient has a prolonged hospital stay, is on mechanical ventilation, and has a history of cough, making him susceptible to developing pneumonia.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to his respiratory status, pneumonia, and possible bacteremia.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient has a history of atrial flutter and is on digoxin and sotalol, which may increase his risk of cardiac complications such as arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
5. Gastrointestinal (GI) Bleeding: The patient has a history of strangulated bowel and is at risk for GI bleeding, especially with his anticoagulation therapy.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a history of thrombocytosis and is at risk for developing thrombocytopenia, especially with his anticoagulation therapy.
7. Hyperkalemia: The patient has a history of hypokalemia and is at risk for developing hyperkalemia, especially with his diuretic therapy.
8. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient has a history of metabolic alkalosis and is at risk for developing further metabolic alkalosis, especially with his diuretic therapy.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is being closely monitored, and his respiratory status is improving with diuresis and oxygen therapy. He is being treated with antibiotics for possible pneumonia, and his anticoagulation therapy is being continued. The patient's cardiac status is being closely monitored, and his digoxin level is being checked regularly. His GI status is being monitored, and he is being treated with prophylactic antibiotics to prevent GI bleeding. His electrolyte levels are being closely monitored, and his potassium levels are being aggressively managed to prevent hyperkalemia.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of PFO repair, recurrent PEs, pulmonary HTN, and dCHF, who is currently in the ICU. The patient's condition is complex and multifactorial.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4Â°C, heart rate of 67 bpm, and blood pressure of 117/57 mmHg. His respiratory status is improving, with an SpO2 of 96% on high-flow oxygen. His cardiac rhythm is normal, and his abdominal examination is soft and non-tender.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 12.0 K/uL, hemoglobin of 8.9 g/dL, and platelet count of 43 K/uL. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a potassium level of 2.7 mEq/L, which is being aggressively managed.

The patient's medical conditions include pulmonary HTN, dCHF, and chronic PEs. He is also at risk for nosocomial pneumonia, VAP, and GI bleed.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Follow-up CTA final read
2. Continue NAC 600 mg x 4
3. Restart lasix gtt today with goal -1 to -2L
4. Continue heparin gtt
5. Check PM electrolytes; replete prn with goal to keep K > 4.5
6. Continue empiric coverage vanc/zosyn for HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP (currently day 6; 8 days total)
7. Follow up cultures
8. Continue high-flow oxygen, but wean today to 40%
9. Continue sildenafil/heparin gtt/digoxin for pulmonary hypertension
10. Continue to monitor digoxin level
11. Send karyotype and determine if further outpatient workup is necessary
12. Continue anticoagulation with heparin gtt
13. Defer restarting home dose Coumadin (if restart, will first start with half dose given concurrent abx)
14. Continue empiric coverage vanc/zosyn for HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP (currently day 6; 8 days total)
15. Follow up culture data

18. Consider transfuse for goal Hct > 21 or unstable
19. Continue to trend
20. Obtain surgical consultation if becomes unstable; otherwise needs keep outpatient surgical follow up
21. Continue sotalol and digoxin as patient currently stable
22. Stop/wean sotalol
23. Continue ISS with change to outpatient regimen when closer to discharge
24. Continue PPI
25. Restart Zocor
26. Continue FEN with replete electrolytes aggressively as on digoxin, sotalol, and lasix gtt, regular diabetic diet
27. Continue prophylaxis with hep gtt, famotidine, bowel regimen with miralax prn constipation
28. Will need PICC line for access after resolution of fevers; try for this PM
29. Will get in touch with patient's father

The patient's disposition is ICU pending clinical improvement.

The patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of PFO repair, recurrent PEs, pulmonary HTN, and dCHF. He was admitted to the ICU with worsening respiratory status after a strangulated hernia repair. He has been treated with diuresis, antibiotics, and anticoagulation. His respiratory status has improved, but he remains on high-flow oxygen and is at risk for pulmonary emboli.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient has a history of recurrent PEs and is at risk for developing another embolism, especially with his current anticoagulation therapy.
2. Nosocomial Pneumonia: The patient has a low-grade fever, leukocytosis, and a questionable infiltrate on CXR, which may be related to nosocomial pneumonia.
3. Volume Overload: The patient has been treated with diuresis, but his fluid balance is still negative, which may indicate ongoing volume overload.
4. Hypokalemia: The patient has been treated with potassium supplements, but his potassium levels are still low, which may indicate ongoing potassium losses.
5. Anemia: The patient has a near 30% Hct, which may be related to prolonged hospital stay and recent surgery with serosanguinous leak from the wound.
6. Thrombocytosis: The patient has a stable thrombocytosis, which may be reactive to his splenectomy.
7. Hypertension: The patient has severe pulmonary HTN, which may be related to his PFO repair and recurrent PEs.
8. Diabetes: The patient has a history of diabetes and is at risk for developing hyperglycemia during his hospital stay.
9. GERD: The patient has a history of GERD and may be at risk for developing aspiration pneumonia.
10. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has a history of hyperlipidemia and may be at risk for developing hypertriglyceridemia during his hospital stay.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is improving, but he remains at risk for various medical complications. The plan is to continue his diuresis, antibiotics, and anticoagulation therapy. The patient's potassium levels will need to be closely monitored and managed, and his anemia will need to be treated with transfusions if necessary. The patient's thrombocytosis will need to be monitored, and his hypertension will need to be managed with medication. The patient's diabetes will need to be closely monitored and managed, and his GERD will need to be treated with medication. The patient's hyperlipidemia will need to be managed with medication and lifestyle changes.

   Assessment and Plan
   41 year old male with a history of PFO repair, recurrent PEs, pulmonary
   HTN, dCHF POD #15 strangulated hernia repair slow vent wean with
   improving hypoxemia and volume overload.
   # Hypoexemia/SOB
   Major player is pulmonary hypertension in the context of chronic
   pulmonary emboli. Also past PFO. Patient also fluid overloaded.
   - Restart coumadin 3 mg daily (previous home daily dose)
 no extra
   doses given antibiotics
   - Heparin drip
   - NAC completed
   - Stop Lasix drip and convert to IV bolus 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] and evaluate
   - Check PM electrolytes; replete prn with goal to keep K > 4.5
   (aggressive KCl repletion given metabolic alkalosis); d/c lasix if Cr
   elevates
   - Continue empiric coverage vanc/zosyn for HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP
   (currently day 7; 8 days total)
   - Follow up cultures
   - Continue high flow oxygen 40%
   # Pulmonary HTN
   Stable, severe. Contributors of PFO, chronic PE, hypercoagulability.
   - Continue sildenafil/heparin gtt/digoxin for pulmonary hypertension
   - Continue to monitor digoxin level
   # Genetic syndrome: Clear dysmorphic features and possibility of
   serious sequelae. Therefore send karyotype and on that basis determine
   if further outpatient workup is necessary.
   - Follow up how to obtain karyotype
   - Hypercoagulable and genetic work-up as outpatient
   # Chronic PEs
   Unclear etiology, likely secondary and also exacerbating pulmonary HTN.
   Patient may also be hypercoagulable and has no spleen and high platelet
   count. Plavix was previously added to regimen as he presumably had clot
   while on therapeutic dose of coumadin. Patient was supposed to have
   hypercoagulable work up in past, but this may be worth revisiting
   (again as an outpatient).  No evidence of new clots since his PFO
   closed. Currently patient remains on hep gtt (plavix stopped).
   - Continue anticoagulation with heparin gtt
   - Defer today on restarting home dose Coumadin (if restart, will first
   start with half dose given concurrent abx)
   - Do not lose track of possible need for plavix and coumadin
   # Fever/leukocytosis. Both are improving likely because of antibiotic
   therapy. WBC now 12, afebrile. Source likely pulmonary. No other
   findings suggestive of infection elsewhere.
   - Continue empiric coverage vanc/zosyn for HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP
   (currently day 6; 8 days total)
   - Follow up culture data
   # Hypokalemia: Will need to be aggressively managed. K goal of 4.5.
   - Check PM electrolytes; replete prn with goal to keep K > 4.5
   (aggressive KCl repletion given metabolic alkalosis)
   # Anemia. Stable. Likely related to prolonged hospital stay and recent
   surgery with serosanguinous leak from wound. Now suppression likely
   given present infection. Given anticoagulation, consider GI bleed.
   - Guaiac stools again if suspicion of losses
   - Continue to trend Hct
   - Consider transfuse for goal Hct > 21 or unstable
   # Thrombocytosis: Stable; likely reactive [**2-4**] splenectomy.
   - Continue to trend
   # h/o strangulated bowel: s/p surgery.  Continue to monitor BMs.
   - Continue daily dressing changes
   - Now daily careful abdominal exams
   - Obtain surgical consultation if becomes unstable; otherwise needs
   keep outpatient surgical follow up
   # h/o a-flutter s/p cardioversion. Continue sotalol and digoxin as
   patient currently stable.  Question continued need for digoxin at this
   time given fact that he is in sinus.  Will ultimately need a
   cardiologist to follow up with re: sotalol.  Patient being
   anticoagulated for other reasons already.
   - Continue to monitor digoxin level
   - Stop/wean sotalol (D/w cardiology)
   # Diabetes: Continue ISS with change to outpatient regimen when closer
   to discharge.
   # GERD: Continue PPI.
   # Hyperlipidemia: Restart Zocor.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 41-year-old male who underwent hernioraphy and is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to difficulty weaning from the ventilator. The patient has a history of pulmonary hypertension, chronic pulmonary emboli, and a patent foramen ovale (PFO) repair.

The patient's current conditions include:

1. Hypoxemia/SOB: The patient's hypoxemia is likely due to pulmonary hypertension in the context of chronic pulmonary emboli, and the patient is also fluid overloaded.
2. Pulmonary HTN: The patient's pulmonary hypertension is stable and severe, with contributors including PFO, chronic PE, and hypercoagulability.
3. Fever/leukocytosis: The patient's fever and leukocytosis are improving likely due to antibiotic therapy, and the source is likely pulmonary.
4. Hypokalemia: The patient's hypokalemia will need to be aggressively managed, with a goal of keeping the potassium level above 4.5.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is stable and likely related to prolonged hospital stay and recent surgery with serosanguinous leak from the wound.
6. Thrombocytosis: The patient's thrombocytosis is stable and likely reactive due to splenectomy.
7. h/o strangulated bowel: The patient's strangulated bowel is s/p surgery, and the patient will need to be monitored for any signs of instability.
8. a-flutter: The patient's a-flutter is s/p cardioversion, and the patient is currently stable on sotalol and digoxin.

The patient is currently receiving the following medications:

* Heparin drip
* Coumadin 3 mg daily
* Lasix drip (stopped and converted to IV bolus 40 mg)
* Vanc/zosyn for HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP
* Sildenafil/heparin gtt/digoxin for pulmonary hypertension
* Sotalol
* Digoxin
* Zocor
* PPI
* Miralax prn for constipation

The patient's labs and radiology results include:

* WBC: 13.0
* Hct: 30.2
* Plt: 998
* Cr: 1.3
* TCO2: 32
* Glucose: 195
* Other labs: PT / PTT / INR: 15.1 / 59.3 / 1.3, ALT / AST: 58 / 22, Alk Phos / T Bili: 45 / 0.9, Differential-Neuts: 70.5%, Lymph: 19.2%, Mono: 5.2%, Eos: 4.7%, LDH: 174 IU/L, Ca++: 8.4 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.9 mg/dL, PO4: 3.9 mg/dL
* CTA: tiny filling defects in the distal subsegmental branches of the pulmonary arteries bilaterally consistent with chronic pulmonary emboli; bilateral patchy ground-glass opacities predominantly in the upper lobes, left greater than right, stable since 11/3, could represent an inflammatory/infectious process; mediastinal adenopathy, stable since 11/3; increased size of main pulmonary artery measuring 3.7 cm consistent with pulmonary arterial hypertension; small hiatal hernia.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Respiratory failure due to pulmonary hypertension and chronic pulmonary emboli
* Sepsis due to HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to a-flutter and sotalol therapy
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to anemia and thrombocytosis
* Renal failure due to hypokalemia and chronic pulmonary emboli
* Hypercoagulability due to PFO and chronic PE
* Infection due to pulmonary emboli and chronic PE

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue empiric coverage for HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP
* Continue sildenafil/heparin gtt/digoxin for pulmonary hypertension
* Continue to monitor digoxin level
* Continue to trend Hct and platelet count
* Obtain surgical consultation for wound care and abdominal exam
* Consider transfusion for goal Hct > 21 or unstable
* Restart Zocor for hyperlipidemia
* Continue PPI for GERD
* Restart Coumadin 3 mg daily
* Continue heparin drip
* Continue to monitor for signs of instability and adjust treatment as necessary.

   ------ Protected Section ------
   # Atrial Flutter (addendum)
   We think atrial flutter was likely exacerbated in the post-operative
   state of fluid overload and possibly worsened thromboembolic pulmonary
   disease. He first had atrial flutter eight years ago which had been
   well controlled with metoprolol tartrate 25 mg [**Hospital1 **]. Digoxin and sotalol
   (80 mg) were started in [**Hospital3 **]. After hernioraphy. I spoke to
   Cardiology about sotalol given that we think this exacerbation and they
   recommended gradual reduction and continued telemetry, starting with a
   reduction from 80 to 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] today with observation. We will want to
   restart his beta-blocker, perhaps as metoprolol succinate for ease of
   dosing. Thus we might work toward, over one to two weeks, stopping
   sotalol and reinstating Toprol 50 mg QD.
   - Reduced sotalol to 40 mg [**Hospital1 **]
   - Will start metoprolol again depending on rate, with a goal of 50 mg

Summary:

The patient is a 41-year-old male who underwent hernioraphy and is currently in the ICU due to difficulties weaning from the ventilator. He has a history of PFO repair, recurrent PEs, pulmonary hypertension, and dCHF. The patient's current conditions include:

* Hypoxemia/SOB: due to pulmonary hypertension and chronic pulmonary emboli
* Pulmonary HTN: stable, severe, and likely exacerbated by PFO and chronic PE
* Fever/leukocytosis: improving, likely due to antibiotic therapy
* Hypokalemia: aggressively managed to maintain K > 4.5
* Anemia: stable, likely related to prolonged hospital stay and recent surgery
* Thrombocytosis: stable, likely reactive to splenectomy
* h/o strangulated bowel: s/p surgery, with continued monitoring of BMs
* a-flutter: s/p cardioversion, with continued treatment with sotalol and digoxin
* Diabetes: managed with ISS, with a plan to change to outpatient regimen when closer to discharge
* GERD: managed with PPI
* Hyperlipidemia: restarted on Zocor

Potential medical complications:

* Pulmonary embolism: given the patient's history of recurrent PEs and chronic pulmonary emboli, there is a risk of further embolism
* Respiratory failure: due to pulmonary hypertension and chronic pulmonary emboli, the patient is at risk of further respiratory failure
* Infection: given the patient's history of surgery and prolonged hospital stay, there is a risk of nosocomial infection
* Thrombosis: given the patient's history of thrombocytosis and anticoagulation therapy, there is a risk of thrombosis
* GI bleed: given the patient's history of anticoagulation therapy and anemia, there is a risk of GI bleed
* Hypercoagulability: given the patient's history of PFO and chronic PE, there is a risk of hypercoagulability
* Genetic syndrome: given the patient's dysmorphic features, there is a risk of a genetic syndrome that may affect his health

Plan:

* Continue empiric coverage for HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP
* Continue anticoagulation with heparin gtt
* Restart Coumadin 3 mg daily
* Monitor digoxin level
* Continue to trend Hct
* Consider transfusion for goal Hct > 21 or unstable
* Continue to monitor BMs
* Obtain surgical consultation if becomes unstable
* Continue to monitor for signs of infection and thrombosis
* Consider genetic testing to determine if the patient has a genetic syndrome
* Continue to manage the patient's other medical conditions, including diabetes, GERD, and hyperlipidemia.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 41-year-old male who underwent hernioraphy and is currently in the ICU due to difficulty weaning from the ventilator. He has a history of PFO repair, recurrent PEs, pulmonary HTN, and dCHF. The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Hypoxemia/SOB: Multifactorial, likely related to pulmonary hypertension, pulmonary edema, and infiltrate/infection.
2. Pulmonary HTN: Stable, severe, with unclear etiology, likely secondary to PFO.
3. Fever/leukocytosis: Improving, likely due to antibiotic therapy, with a source likely pulmonary.
4. Hypokalemia: Will need aggressive management to maintain a goal of 4.5.
5. Anemia: Stable, likely related to prolonged hospital stay, recent surgery, and infection.
6. Thrombocytosis: Stable, likely reactive to splenectomy.
7. h/o strangulated bowel: S/p surgery, with continued monitoring of BMs and daily dressing changes.
8. h/o a-flutter: S/p cardioversion, with continued sotalol and digoxin therapy, but questioning the continued need for digoxin.
9. Diabetes: Continuing ISS with a change to outpatient regimen when closer to discharge.
10. GERD: Continuing PPI therapy.
11. Hyperlipidemia: Restarting Zocor.
12. FEN: No IVF, with aggressive repletion of electrolytes as on digoxin, sotalol, and lasix gtt, and regular diabetic diet.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Pulmonary embolism: Given the patient's history of recurrent PEs and chronic PEs, there is a risk of new clots forming.
2. Infection: The patient's fever and leukocytosis suggest a possible infection, which may worsen if not properly managed.
3. Pulmonary hypertension: The patient's severe pulmonary hypertension may lead to further complications, such as right heart failure.
4. Hypokalemia: Aggressive management of hypokalemia is necessary to prevent further complications.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to complications such as heart failure or decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
6. Thrombocytosis: The patient's thrombocytosis may increase the risk of bleeding or thrombotic complications.
7. h/o strangulated bowel: The patient's history of strangulated bowel may lead to complications such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
8. h/o a-flutter: The patient's history of a-flutter may lead to complications such as atrial fibrillation or flutter, which may worsen his cardiac condition.
9. Diabetes: The patient's diabetes may worsen if not properly managed, leading to complications such as ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome.
10. GERD: The patient's GERD may worsen if not properly managed, leading to complications such as aspiration pneumonia or esophageal stricture.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, I recommend the following:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's oxygenation and ventilation status.
2. Aggressively manage the patient's hypokalemia and anemia.
3. Continue antibiotic therapy for suspected infection.
4. Monitor the patient's pulmonary hypertension and consider further management options.
5. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's thrombocytosis.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's bowel status and consider further management options if necessary.
7. Continue to manage the patient's diabetes and consider further management options if necessary.
8. Continue to manage the patient's GERD and consider further management options if necessary.
9. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's pulmonary embolism.
10. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's a-flutter.

   41 year old male with a history of PFO repair, recurrent PEs, pulmonary
   HTN, dCHF POD #15 strangulated hernia repair slow vent wean with
   improving hypoxemia and volume overload.
   # Hypoexemia/SOB
   Major player is pulmonary hypertension in the context of chronic
   pulmonary emboli. Also past PFO (contributor to pulmonary hypertension)
   and patient also fluid overloaded (by about 15 kg from estimated dry
   weight based on OSH notes). Patient producing more sputum now, so will
   need to follow. No suspicion of PNA at this time.
   - Treatment of chronic PE as below.
   - Continue Lasix IV 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] (need to dose with care given fragile
   hemodynamics
 preload dependent
 but has tolerated about
 1 L daily
   well
 is now down ~ 7 L from admission)
 check Lytes [**Hospital1 **] given Lasix
   - Follow CXRs
   - Check PM electrolytes; replete prn with goal to keep K > 4.5
   (aggressive KCl repletion given metabolic alkalosis); d/c lasix if Cr
   elevates
   - Empiric coverage vanc/zosyn for HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP to stop
   tonight (currently day 8; 8 days total)
   - Follow up cultures
   - Continue low flow oxygen by mask (15L) with n.c. for meal times.
   # Chronic Pulmonary Emboli
   Had another PE on coumadin in the past, per OSH note. Therefore was on
   Plavix plus coumadin. Patient reports not tolerating Plavix. Apparently
   hypercoagulable work-up as outpatient, but may be fruitfully revisited.
   Thrombocytosis (s/p splenectomy) may be a contributor. Therefore:
   - ASA 81 mg and coumadin
   - Change from heparin gtt to Lovenox 90 mg [**Hospital1 **] for ease of dosing on
   floor
   - Coumadin 3 mg QD
   # Pulmonary HTN
   Stable, severe. Contributors of PFO, chronic PE, hypercoagulability.
   - Continue sildenafil and digoxin for pulmonary hypertension
   - Treatment of chronic PE as above
   - Stop monitoring digoxin level
 has been stable and can be checked
   again before discharge
   - Pumonary consult and to follow on floor
   # Genetic syndrome: Clear dysmorphic features and possibility of
   serious sequelae. Therefore send karyotype and on that basis determine
   if further outpatient workup is necessary.
   - Karyotype, syndromal, potential further hypercoagulable work-up as
   outpatient.
   # Fever/leukocytosis. Both are improving likely because of antibiotic
   therapy. WBC now 12, afebrile. Source likely pulmonary. No other
   findings suggestive of infection elsewhere.
   - Continue empiric coverage vanc/zosyn for HAP/nosocomial pneumonia/VAP
   (currently day 6; 8 days total)
   - Follow up culture data
   # Hypokalemia: Will need to be aggressively managed. K goal of 4.5.
   - Check PM electrolytes; replete prn with goal to keep K > 4.5
   (aggressive KCl repletion given metabolic alkalosis)
   # Anemia. Stable. Likely related to prolonged hospital stay and recent
   surgery with serosanguinous leak from wound. Now suppression likely
   given present infection. Given anticoagulation, consider GI bleed.
   - Guaiac stools again if suspicion of losses
   - Continue to trend Hct
   - Consider transfuse for goal Hct > 21 or unstable
   # Thrombocytosis: Stable; likely reactive [**2-4**] splenectomy.
   - Continue to trend
   # h/o strangulated bowel: s/p surgery.  Continue to monitor BMs.
   Incision does not look infected, but ooze likely secondary to
   anticoagulation.
   - Continue daily dressing changes
   - Now daily careful abdominal exams
   - Obtain surgical consultation if becomes unstable; otherwise needs
   keep outpatient surgical follow up
   # h/o a-flutter s/p cardioversion. Continue sotalol and digoxin as
   patient currently stable. Patient being anticoagulated for other
   reasons already. Digoxin level stable at around 0.6. Attempt to wean
   sotalol resulted in flutter again.
   - Monitor digoxin in a few days now
   - Continue sotalol and digoxin
 do not restart home metoprolol given

   # Diabetes: Continue ISS with change to outpatient regimen when closer
   to discharge.

   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes aggressively as on digoxin, sotalol

Summary:

The patient is a 41-year-old male admitted to the ICU after undergoing a strangulated hernia repair. He has a history of pulmonary hypertension, chronic pulmonary emboli, and a patent foramen ovale (PFO). He is currently experiencing respiratory failure and is having difficulty weaning off ventilator support. He has been prescribed various medications, including anticoagulants, diuretics, and beta-blockers, and is being treated for chronic pulmonary emboli and pulmonary hypertension.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient has a history of chronic pulmonary emboli and is at risk for developing another embolism.
2. Atrial Flutter: The patient has a history of atrial flutter and is currently being treated with sotalol and digoxin.
3. Hypokalemia: The patient has hypokalemia and is at risk for developing cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Anemia: The patient has anemia and is at risk for developing further complications, such as cardiac failure.
5. Thrombocytosis: The patient has thrombocytosis and is at risk for developing bleeding complications.
6. Infection: The patient has a fever and leukocytosis, which may indicate an infection.
7. Hypercoagulability: The patient has a hypercoagulable state and is at risk for developing further thrombotic events.
8. Metabolic Alkalosis: The patient has metabolic alkalosis and is at risk for developing further complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias.
9. Cardiac Failure: The patient has cardiac failure and is at risk for developing further complications, such as pulmonary edema.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's pulmonary embolism risk and adjust treatment accordingly.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's atrial flutter and adjust treatment accordingly.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's hypokalemia and adjust treatment accordingly.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and adjust treatment accordingly.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's thrombocytosis and adjust treatment accordingly.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's infection risk and adjust treatment accordingly.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's hypercoagulability risk and adjust treatment accordingly.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's metabolic alkalosis and adjust treatment accordingly.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac failure risk and adjust treatment accordingly.

ICU Care:

1. Continue to provide mechanical ventilation support as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and adjust treatment accordingly.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's laboratory values and adjust treatment accordingly.
4. Continue to provide prophylactic antibiotics as needed.
5. Continue to provide anticoagulant therapy as needed.
6. Continue to provide diuretic therapy as needed.
7. Continue to provide beta-blocker therapy as needed.
8. Continue to provide stress ulcer prophylaxis as needed.
9. Continue to provide VAP prophylaxis as needed.

   surgery with serosanguinous leak from wound. Now suppression likely
   given present infection. Given anticoagulation, consider GI bleed.
   - Guaiac stools again if suspicion of losses
   - Continue to trend Hct
   - Consider transfuse for goal Hct > 21 or unstable
   # Thrombocytosis: Stable; likely reactive [**2-4**] splenectomy.
   - Continue to trend
   # h/o strangulated bowel: s/p surgery.  Continue to monitor BMs.
   - Continue daily dressing changes
   - Now daily careful abdominal exams
   - Obtain surgical consultation if becomes unstable; otherwise needs
   keep outpatient surgical follow up
   # h/o a-flutter s/p cardioversion. Continue sotalol and digoxin as
   patient currently stable.  Question continued need for digoxin at this
   time given fact that he is in sinus.  Will ultimately need a
   cardiologist to follow up with re: sotalol.  Patient being
   anticoagulated for other reasons already.
   - Continue to monitor digoxin level
   - Stop/wean sotalol (D/w cardiology)
   # Diabetes: Continue ISS with change to outpatient regimen when closer
   to discharge.
   # GERD: Continue PPI.
   # Hyperlipidemia: Restart Zocor.

   and lasix gtt, regular diabetic diet
